results.title: Private eye
results.creator_credit: Geoff Tyson, Peter McKinley, Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry and Tasfilm Productions
results.brief_description:
This 1970 film demonstrates the importance of eye safety and shows various methods of protection. The film opens with a sequence in film noir style of a ‘private eye’ working a case, with this gimmick interspersed throughout the film. It shows industrial working scenarios and various examples of eye protection, including safety glasses and helmets with visors.

Produced by Tasfilm Productions for the Department of Labour and Industry, Tasmania, and presented by Protector Sureguard.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: But you're a girl
results.creator_credit: Julie Ruth, Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology and Sue Johnston
results.brief_description: Shows some of the areas girls have traditionally worked in are no longer certain providers of jobs and then goes on to look at other job options such as trades, apprenticeships and traditionally male dominated professions. Indicates that is is possible for girls and young women to enter these areas, do well in them and enjoy them.

results.title: The Fair go: winning the 1967 referendum
results.creator_credit: Pat Laughren, Open Learning Agency of Australia and Canute Films
results.brief_description: This documentary commemorates the 10 year campaign that won an unprecedented 90.77% Yes vote in the 1967 Referendum about Indigenous citizenship. Until that referendum the people of the oldest civilisation in the world were not counted as citizens in their own land. Told through personal interviews and rare archival footage, this film details the efforts of the people who helped change the Constitution. Narrated by Deborah Mailman.

results.title: Not Crippled, Not Useless
results.brief_description: Michael Briffa is fourteen and will probably be confined to a wheelchair for the rest of his life. This program explores Michael’s determination and success in being allowed to enrol in an ordinary school. As well, Michael’s parents discuss their attitudes to special schools.

results.title: Solid women = Moodeitj yorgas
results.creator_credit: Deborah Howlett, Tracey Moffatt and Western Australian Women's Advisory Council to the Premier
results.brief_description: This documentary about Aboriginal women today includes interviews with successful, strong Aboriginal women, including Sally Morgan, Lois Olney, Helen Corbett and Helen Dorondorf. Stills of Aboriginal people and the land, stories in two Aboriginal languages about their fate after the white man, and Aboriginal music and dance are presented between the interviews. The women raise issues about how the Aboriginal people can best help themselves, and recount their own life experiences and achievements. Highly successful, these women act as a foil to the bulk of information received through the media about Aboriginal people. They are positive role models for Aboriginal women and girls.

results.title: Daintree: The Vanishing Rainforest
results.creator_credit: John Richardson, Danae Gunn and Kestrel Films (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
This video is Part 5 in a series of 6 documentaries that examine the wilderness areas of Australia. A child returns from the future, a time when forests no longer exist and we see the rainforest and its most unusual inhabitants through her eyes. She grows to love the forest and cannot understand some of the things she sees happening. This is an imaginative and fascinating story which emphasises the delicate balance of nature, and how easily it can be destroyed. A Teacher’s guide accompanies the video.

results.title: Walk softly: minimal impact bushwalking
results.brief_description: The rise in popularity of outdoor recreation has led to a vast increase in the number of bushwalkers visiting national parks and wilderness areas. With this rise in use has come increasing damage to the natural environment. Fortunately, a new bushwalking ethic has developed and the “Minimal Impact Bushwalking” philosophy is now widely adopted by bushwalkers. This program covers the major Minimal Impact Bushwalking techniques.

results.title: Snow safe
results.creator_credit: Australian Ski Patrol Association and Jack Creswick
results.brief_description: A well produced video looking at all aspects of ski and snow safety. Covers appropriate clothing and equipment, selection of equipment, getting proper ski instruction, ski slope courtesy and behaviour, using lifts, ski slope signs, what to do in case of accident or getting lost, care of children, food and hypothermia, and safe tobogganing. Narrated by Debbie Byrne.

results.title: Rolf Harris: How to Draw Fun Cartoons
results.brief_description: Yes, it’s the distinctive cartoons, drawings and humour of the unstoppable Rolf Harris and it’s Rolf Harris in person taking you through your very own “learn to draw” lesson. “You can draw”, says Rolf Harris. “We all can. It’s just a matter of knowing that you can draw your way”. How to draw fun cartoons, will give you as much pleasure watching as it will when you try out Rolf’s methods for yourself. Don’t say “I can’t draw” anymore, let Rolf Harris show you how.

results.title: Early Melbourne: from village to town
results.creator_credit: Lily Steiner, TV Ed Productions, Seven Network Limited (Australia) and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: Dr Bernard Barrett, State Historian, discusses the early development of Melbourne, covering such topics as the naming of Melbourne, who decided where the streets would be located and what they would be called.
